Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Processing Prosody and Syntax in Turkish

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates the role of prosody (intonation and rhythm of speech) in the processing of syntax in Turkish. Many experiments have shown that the prosody with which a sentence is uttered can provide listeners with cues to its syntactic structure; some have also observed that an inappropriate prosodic contour can mislead the syntactic parsing routines, causing comprehension difficulty. It has been proposed that when prosodic cues are not supportive of the syntactic structure, the language processing mechanism ignores the prosodic input and relies on syntactic parsing strategies such as Late Closure (a locality preference). However, a closer look at the available findings suggests that the lengths of phrases could have caused what appeared to be an effect of default syntactic strategies, since it is known that phrase lengths can influence the perceived informativeness of prosodic cues.

In the present study, four experiments will be conducted to distinguish these alternative explanations. Misleading and facilitatory effects of prosody will be examined in Turkish, a language that is typologically different from more commonly studied languages (such as English) and has properties well-suited to this purpose. Phrase lengths will be systematically manipulated in all experimental sentences, such that optimal-length prosodic phrasing is associated with late closure syntax in one condition, and with early closure syntax in the other.

This study will make an original contribution to current knowledge about the mental mechanisms underlying human sentence processing. Outcomes for Turkish similar to those for previously studied languages would strengthen the general hypothesis that prosody-syntax interactions are guided by fundamental universal properties of the human parsing mechanism. The specific results will disentangle two potential accounts of how that mechanism responds to imperfect input with conflicting cues, as is not uncommon in everyday language use. Other potential contributions include text-to-speech/speech-to-text software development in Turkish with a wide range of applications including programs to aid the visually handicapped.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant, Nazik Dinctopal-Deniz completed five psycholinguistic experiments for her dissertation on the processing of prosody and syntax in Turkish. Nazik’s research investigated the ways in which the human language processing mechanism responds to speech rhythm and melody as well as to word sequence and sentence structure. Her research confirmed that listeners are sensitive to the prosodic patterns of sentences while computing syntactic structure and meaning, and it resolved an ambiguity in prior research findings concerning how listeners cope with misleading prosody.

During her funding period, Nazik spent two months in Turkey collecting data from native speakers of Turkish. She has become experienced in designing experiments in psycholinguistics and in using data analysis software such as DMDX, Praat and R. Thanks to the funds provided by the NSF, Nazik was able to travel to domestic and international conferences in her field, disseminating her results, and meeting with scholars who conduct research similar to hers and exchanging ideas with them.

Nazik completed her Ph.D. dissertation in July 2014. This work is an important contribution to the research literature in psycholinguistics because it confirms that rhythmic factors can interact significantly with sentence structure as listeners and readers assign meaning to sentences. Recognizing the role of prosody in language comprehension has potential implications for text-to-speech, speech-to-text software development, which has very many applications in current information technology, including tools for aiding visually handicapped people. It can also inform studies of age-related comprehension problems and impairments such as aphasia, and may contribute to the development of remedial strategies.

Nazik assumed a tenure-track assistant professorship position in Turkey in August 2014, which gives her an international opportunity to add to, and to transmit to others, the knowledge she gained through her Ph.D. studies.
